review_title: Great Job to Have If You're a Student
job_title: Academic Technology Assistant II in Austin, TX
pros: - Management is competent and cares about its employees - Whenever there's significant downtime, you can study/work on school assignments -Chill and not demanding; easy to understand what you need to do in order to be successful in this job
cons: I don't have any concerns at the moment. I would only say that some students/teachers can be very rude, but I think that comes w/ customer service in general. We are allowed to stand our ground in case there's blatant harassment and can ask them to leave and/or call campus police.

pros: Full-time faculty and staff employees who work in full-time and/or part-time positions at the college are eligible for ACC medical benefits.
cons: Culture thick with Nepotism. Workplace full of bullying. No action from HR when formal grievances are filed.

pros: Great leadership Passionate people Great mission
cons: The institution, like many others right now, is struggling to find the right talent in a competitive market which can result in things moving slower than is ideal.

pros: Benefits, time off & great co-workers.
cons: Not remote work or remote work options.

job_title: College Advising and Admissions Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: Benefits & Retirement, Time Off.
cons: Culture thick with Nepotism. Workplace full of bullying. No action from HR when formal grievances are filed. No workplace consistency or procedures working in Enrollment and Advising. Top heavy salary culture, low salary for staff actually working the positions. No management accountability. Difficult workplace atmosphere. Hiring committees don't even matter -- when a hiring committee makes a decision as a unit, it can be trumped by the hiring manager for political/personal gain. Therefore, what is the purpose of a hiring committee?

pros: Great place to learn and gain experience.
cons: Small team - but focused.

They only said "your pay will not be affected by these changes" which now feels like a huge lie.

review_title: Great Way to Build Skills for Self and Others
job_title: Supplemental Instruction Leader in Austin, TX
pros: Being an S.I. Leader at ACC is a low-stress way to both help fellow students learn, and to cement knowledge you've previously absorbed in class. It is also a great way to make friends and find a community of people interested in the same subject(s).
cons: Depending on at which campus the correlating class was held, available times and rooms available for S.I. study sessions were limited and sometimes just assigned. This could make it difficult for students who worked and/or had conflicting schedules, often leading to low attendance. Pre-pandemic this was more of an issue, and virtual sessions made this easier for some but not all students . I hope schedules post-pandemic will do more to accommodate working and busy students who want to benefit from the supplemental instruction program at ACC.

job_title: Assistant Lab Tech in Round Rock, TX

cons: More flexibility as a full time student and gives you more benefits for your goals and success.

pros: ACC offers a platform for educators to impact and improve the lives of students, many of who have been disadvantaged by society.
cons: ACC allows some regressive ideologies to manifest within their staff. There's even some open bigotry on some social media accounts of professors. Horrible pay for essentially creating a class from scratch.

review_title: ACC: A Great Place to Work and Study

pros: ACC offers its employees many opportunities for professional growth.

pros:
Supervisors and coworkers really care and take pride in their work.
Treated like a professional, given the agency to do job w/out being micromanaged.
Bi-yearly paid training exercises are actually good and not cookie-cutter, outsourced crap.
Make your own schedule and amount of hours. No pressure to schedule additional hours or inconvenient shifts.
No SS tax :).
cons:
Part-time offers no benefits.
Work is seasonal based on school semesters. Long periods w/out pay.
Few opportunities for advancement/FT roles and positions are competitive with many non-negotiable requirements (yrs experience/degree/etc..., employment history and ability not taken into account).

review_title: Great organization made greater by kind coworkers
pros: Excellent workplace culture, full of friendly people, lots of downtime. If you mess up they will let you know exactly what you did wrong and what to do next time.
cons: Organizational issues sometimes lead to unclear expectations, you must be willing to ask for clarification or use your best judgement. You must learn to fix problems swiftly in front of a large audience.

review_title: Adjunct Positions are Highly Sought After, but Not Well-Paid or Always Stable
pros: ACC gives a lot of freedom to its instructors, though we have been extremely stressed through the pandemic. It is a fast-institution, and ranked highly in many fields compared with other community colleges. Most of my colleagues have been teaching in my department since I started there, ten years ago.
cons: Classes are parceled out to a fairly large adjunct pool each semester, and while Highest Priority to Hire status almost guarantees consistent and thoughtful course assignments, courses with low enrollment are canceled at the last minute. There is very little compensation for those who lose classes, and ACC does not offer health care benefits to its adjuncts. It pays better than most institutions, but it is still not a living wage by any means, and adjuncts are prevented from teaching more than three courses per semester.

pros: Working at ACC as an ambassador gave me confidence I have today in my job post graduation. While some part time jobs are great for paychecks, the skills I gained at ACC I am definitely using now. You can learn how to follow a schedule anywhere, but I learned to take initiatives and enhance my communication skills here. The advisors are amazing and where always there when needed. I was able to work around my class schedule easily and honestly was the perfect job while I was there.

review_title: Amazing work environment with driven and kind colleagues.
pros: They're very flexible with scheduling. My colleagues were always kind and helpful with my acclimation. The director was involved at all levels and promoted a great work environment. Although working with children can be hard at times, the children were a joy to work with and the work was rewarding. This is a great job for college students that are interested in child development, psychology, or early education. I learned a lot from my brief employment, and I was able to maintain a manageable work/life balance.
cons: I genuinely can't think of any cons I experienced while working there. It was a great experience that was cut too short by the pandemic.

pros: Flexible schedule, manageable student hours, friendly community.
cons: None really! Great place to work!

pros: Autonomy in the classroom, opportunities to network with other professors and administrators, opportunities for professional development free of charge, lots of campuses and centers at which to teach, instructional support, clear and effective curriculum, and an overall phenomenal approach by the college to connecting education and community.
cons: Adjunct professors cannot live off of what they earn--salaries are deplorably and shockingly LOW. Add to this the difficulty of getting classes to teach (because the review process weighs far too heavily on student evaluations of teachers, which determines an adjunct's ranking), and it's almost  not worth trying to get a teaching job at ACC. My students' evaluations ranked me at "excellent" for a total of 7 years and "very good" for a total of 4 years. A "very good" rating knocked me out of the first level of adjunct assignments into the second level. Additionally, because of the ranking system used, far too many adjuncts being hired (which means there are more teachers than there are classes to teach), and retired full-time professors being given classes before currently employed adjuncts, even adjuncts who've been with ACC 15+ years are put on the same level as new hires--seniority makes no difference--and often get no classes or only one or two. Finally, some departments are so huge that Dept. Chairs rarely know the people who work for them.

review_title: Great mission, lots of opportunities to contribute
pros: Great colleagues, fair wages, good opps for growth
cons: It's a large bureaucratic organization, sometimes it takes years to get approval to buy post it notes! (That's an exaggeration of course)

pros: Comp is ok, but benefits kind of suck for public sector
cons: Very disorganized. Cronyism is rampant. Purchasing is like dealing with morons on a nuclear physics problem.

pros: Great, diverse staff teams across the school. People are very genuine. Very stable work environment overall.
cons: There aren't many opportunities to advance your career and pay is low. Human Resources will stonewall you if you don't meet exact job posting requirements and Administration favors external candidates that they can groom.

pros: IT was a place I enjoyed going to in the morning. I was handed projects and allowed to complete them as best I could. I felt a part of something bigger, supporting staff, administration, faculty and students. I felt the objective was to provide a service all could trust and find beneficial.
cons: Things change. We all have the option of putting up or shutting up. When you rely on a job for a living, to have it jacked around with is a scary thing. Upper management could swing like a pendulum: One moment you are overwhelmed, next you find you responsibilities usurped by someone that doesn't know how to work with others and do things in a unilateral and arbitrary way without  consulting others. This tendency does nothing but alienate co-workers and as a result projects have no backup and many times are incomplete. As a result, the department gets a bad rap because no one knows why things aren't getting done.

pros: Open communication, autonomy, good wages
cons: Hours limited to 19 per week

pros: I liked the place and the students
cons: Payment are really low and no chance for any raise

pros: It was fun teaching other students, and got paid
cons: Not really many cons, It was good work

pros: Great for students who are taking classes and want to earn extra money and experience.
cons: No cons. They work easily with your schedule.

pros: Variety of professional educational paths and trade skills to pursue; exceptional staff and educators

pros: Great people to work with

job_title: Adjunct ESL Instructor in Austin, TX
pros: I was impressed with the availability of technology in the classroom although I had to quickly establish a relationship with the Media department of each campus I worked on.  There are 7 campuses in Austin, so it was easy to live somewhere with a close proximity to one or more  campuses.  Other pros include direct deposit, system that allows you to evaluate your supervisors, assigned mentor as a new adjunct, use of gmail, etc.
cons: There is a lottery type of complicated system to receive class assignments which seemed a little convoluted.  As an adjunct, when I taught multiple classes, this  often necessitated working at 2 or more more campuses.  At one campus (SAC), the copy room staff was unhelpful and rarely kept the supplies stocked.  For the area, it seemed to offer low pay, and like many community colleges, there were very few full-time teaching opportunities, so I had no opportunity to gain benefits, etc.

job_title: Student Services Tech Specialist in Austin, TX
pros: Mostly great people working at the college. Staff and faculty genuinely demonstrate concern for students and doing the right thing. Compensation is competitive and college is stable.
cons: Extremely fast growth (multiple campuses opening in past couple years) have stretched resources. Even with new campuses opening, existing campuses tend to be extremely overcrowded, with little room for staff or class expansion. This further impacts students by not being able to offer sufficient courses to meet demand in popular subjects/programs. Operating practices are an odd mix of high tech and antiquated manual operations leading to confusion at times and downright system failure at others (e.g., student record system going down during the peak of registration).

pros: The upper management are well-intentioned, enlightened people who care about education. The learning labs are well supported, offering free tutoring on a wide variety of subjects and at many locations.
cons: Teaching loads are too high (36 units per year for full-time faculty!) 15 units (5 classes) fall and spring PLUS 6 units (2 classes) in the summer. I have been tenured at two other community colleges and never faced a teaching load this extreme. There is a HUGE disconnect between upper management and the everyday faculty/student interactions. This disconnect makes real change seemingly impossible.

job_title: Student Services Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: lots of vacation and sick days, generous benefits package, free classes (3 max per year), fun environment
cons: pay is not competitive and salary scales are confusing, too many changes that impact student enrollment

review_title: Benefits are great, but the technology is outdated and there's too much red tape.
pros: The benefits. You basically get 6 weeks off a year and plenty of sick leave. Project deadlines are very flexible. You don't have to take work home with you.
cons: People aren't held accountable for their work. They rarely fire even the worst employees. Raises are given across the board and are not based on merit. Imagine an environment where you can't get fired for doing a bad job and don't get rewarded for doing a good job and you have ACC.

review_title: One of the most rewarding places to work!
pros:
A staff of people who are dedicated to improving the lives of students here in Central Texas.
An internal process that recognizes the value of individual initiative and encourages everyone to do their best.
Consistent opportunities to interact with staff from other departments/disciplines.
Focus on "outcome oriented" success rather than just "checking a box" and pushing a student along.
Constant discussions and efforts designed to be more effective and successful in the process of educating and helping students.
cons:
Traffic between locations can be difficult. 
Many times, simply because of the proximity of one campus to another, there are opportunities for improved communication and marketing of events, accomplishments and staff achievements across a variety of departments.

pros:
Paid holidays
Good benefits
No evenings or weekends (for the most part).
cons: The pay doesn't reflect the job responsibilities. I am a returning employee, and my compensation offer was substantially lower than the salary I left making. Different job title, very related skills. From what I understand, there have been budget cuts and what took 5 years to get salary wise, now takes 10. That's a bit discouraging because some employees go above and beyond to help students, and deserve a pay that reflects their effort.

review_title: It was great, I would go back if I still lived in Austin.
pros: The pay was pretty good for the job and full benefits were nice.  Great group of people to work with.  Paid holidays - when the college is closed you don't work so you'll get a nice break for Christmas and Thanksgiving.  Schedule never really changed it was a normal M-F/8-5.  Tuition wavers were very nice 3 free classes a year.
cons: Just needs a little upgrading still using paper documents that should be converted to electronic format or at least given the option to do either - lots of paperwork.

pros: I love teaching and I've been an English and Business Writing professor for eleven years.  Since I have a great love for the English language, I take great pleasure when I witness a student begin to see how important language and communication are.  Even better, I learn from the students as well.
cons: Since I'm adjunct faculty, I don't teach full-time.  Therefore, I don't make the salary I need to sustain my family.  I live in Fredericksburg, so I'm unable to take on as many classes as I would were I to live in Austin.

job_title: Assistant Director of Alumni Relations in Austin, TX
pros:
-Excellent Human Resources benefits with lots of professional development training, mentorship, and opportunities.

-Emphasis on student success--so every department is open to ways incubate new ideas to support this model.

-Employees are encouraged to participate in shared leadership opportunities

-Great discounts for ride sharing, metro passes, and well priced parking options

-Invested interest in Equity and Inclusion
cons:
-The school is in a huge growth phase and is working to break the communication silos that can emerge with 12 campuses and over 150 majors.

-While the administration is good about empowering individuals to try new ideas and programs--getting the funding is not always easy.

-As with any large academic or government institution---red tape and bureaucracy prevails

pros: Lots of support, workshops, insurance, and very steady work. Depending on campus the attention to detail and upper level support vary, but I have had no negative issues. People pretty much keep to themselves, and very little to no drama across departments. Usually recognized for good work in more than one way. Happy to have this job!
cons: Very hard to advance in certain areas. Will have to wait 5-15 years to get a promotion unless I switch departments. Little reasons to try hard or your best.

review_title: Would not recommend for IT position
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Laid back atmosphere for the most part.
cons: The person running the IT department has no interest in anyone but themselves. Declaring themselves smarter than anyone in the IT department and ignoring all input from staff can lead to a very frustrating experience.  They have promoted desktop support personnel into System Engineering roles that are beyond their capabilities and expect them to be successful. They lead by fear and dominance. I saw quite a few good people that had been with ACC many, many years run off because their views differed from the new management.

review_title: Bureaucracy Riddled with Inefficiencies and Incompetence
pros: Ability to directly assist students and your community, vacation/time off is extremely generous, decent healthcare.
cons: Where to I begin? The HR department needs to be gutted.  They never return phone calls or emails queries, have a subpar on boarding process (it doesn't exist), send out communication with private information (letters, emails, etc) to the incorrect people, and make the similar errors when submitting paperwork to healthcare providers and retirement accounts. Everything stems from HR.

review_title: Many things make this a frustrating place to work
pros: Robust health, retirement and professional development benefits.
cons: There are so many employees who do nothing all day in order to protect their job and ultimately their benefits. Those who are "do-ers" have to pick up the slack.

review_title: Depends on Which Department and Which Campus
job_title: Northridge Campus Chair in Austin, TX
pros:
* Casual atmosphere (again, dependent upon department)
* Flexible Hours
* Friendly, welcoming, helpful co-workers
cons: * There's a learning curve for navigating all of the paperwork and forms that you have to learn by trial and error.  (Once you hit a brick wall, people are willing to help, though.)

pros:
Adjunct classes for the Early College Start program are usually on interesting subjects. I got to teach the British Literature class to high-school seniors and had a really good experience with Beowulf and other classics. 

There is a lot of freedom to develop the classes in the manner that you want, but don't go overboard because they do have some requirements, especially for the writing classes.

Scheduling is usually pretty flexible, and as long as you follow the minimal guidelines and teach the classes well enough to get good reviews, then usually you have a "high recommendation" status for new classes.
cons:
As an adjunct, you don't really interact with other professors or other teachers at the schools where you teach. You can feel really isolated. I ended up emailing my teaching mentor from the first semester, so at least you have a point of contact that can be useful for brainstorming and even sharing stories.

Obviously adjuncts lack all the benefits and pay of full-time professors (and even high school teachers, who essentially teach the same material as you do). Also, this is a program where high schoolers are skipping their AP/IB English classes to take "college-level" ACC courses, so public schools are basically saving money on full-time teachers by shoveling students into these adjunct-taught ones.

My main frustrations, overall, related to management. The students and classes themselves were fine. I do wish that the high schoolers were given more introduction to college-level courses. I had to make the curriculum and format of the class a lot more similar to high school because they still didn't understand some of the basics of turning in homework and studying for tests.

pros: Friendly co-workers, felt like a family.  Excellent Benefits, Time Off, and Professional Development. Most of the staff really cared about students succeeding. Excellent Work/Life Balance.
cons: Low pay, higher administrators have goals, and try to make changes that are not reasonable. Goals should be attainable.

job_title: Learning Lab Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Convenient location for me, I had all classes and worked at the same campus. Flexibility with schedule. I worked in the EVC Learning Lab, and the staff and supervisor were both very easy and enjoyable to work with.
cons: Maximum 20 hours per week, no availability of work hours when classes are out- which is of course when I had plenty of time to work. That is just how it is with work study though, your total allowable earnings are decided at the beginning of each semester, and if you go over at all than you don't get paid for that time.

review_title: Fast-growing school and overall a great place to work.
pros: ACC is a fast-growing school and overall a great place to work. The people around me were always willing to take time out of their day to  helping you if needed.
cons: Compensation was just okay for my years of experience and education. There was no opportunity for advancement that I could see from my position. Little to no collaboration. Office politics - there is definitely and "in" group that is difficult to penetrate, but generally, people are friendly nonetheless.  My supervisor was rarely visible or available.

pros:
I loved my time at ACC, mostly due to working with excellent students, teachers, and department. I found it rewarding, especially working with low income students and feeling like I was making a difference in their lives.

Relaxed pace. Job security and flexibility. Excellent compensation for salaried faculty.

BTW, because everyone is a public employee, you can find actual salaries via searching the internet.
cons:
For anyone who isn't salaried faculty:

You're working for the state and it feels like it. People stick around and get comfy, lazy, and apathetic. The progressive discipline policy makes it virtually impossible to change poor behavior. There's a lot of folks doing other people's work in order to make things run. Most of these folks are paid extremely poorly, making it hard to attract good candidates.

They say that if most folks were the boss for a day, they'd give themselves the day off. ACC is no different and if you work there, you will likely have the opportunity to be an unrepentant slacker with no consequences.

I would NOT recommend ACC to anyone who has a tendency to do more than what's expected. You will not be compensated and you can do more good for people elsewhere in Austin. You're essentially taking a pay cut for incredible job stability and flexibility.

I was not an adjunct but I think there are some very shady practices in paying adjuncts and lack of health benefits. It's a lawsuit waiting to happen...

Also my department was really positive and awesome but some departments are completely disfunctional and there's simply nothing to be done except wait for people to retire...

review_title: A great place to work if you work it to your advantage!
pros: Great benefits to include Winter and Spring Breaks. Flexibility, supports gaining additional degrees while working. Great people.
cons: Too many exceptions to the rules. Whoever yells the loudest gets it. The top is scared to make decisions until its too late which causes decisions to be made by default. College needs automation of forms.  There isn't any upward mobility; flat organization.

job_title: Adjunct Reference Librarian in Austin, TX
pros: Decent hourly rate of pay, simple clear job tasks, and it's very enjoyable and inspiring to work with community college students.
cons: As an hourly employee, there are very few benefits, and no health insurance at all.  The college takes so many breaks that it amounts to only 42 weeks of work per year.  Limited to 19 hours per week.

job_title: Computer Support Technician in Austin, TX
pros:
Fun to work with smart people - faculty, staff and students will keep you on your toes.
Pay is average, but benefits are good - employee health insurance premiums are paid for, and there is a pension plan (vested after 5 years service).
cons: Some bureaucracy to deal with - some antiquated IT systems.  No clear defined path for upward mobility.

pros: Incredibly supportive department from office support to department chair. Supervisors were encouraging and willing to give recognition for good work. Excellent resources and a willingness to go the extra mile for employees. Beautiful new campus in Round Rock.
cons: While adjunct work is difficult by nature and community colleges can foster a sense of disconnectedness when there are multiple campuses, these effects were minimal at ACC. Really, the only big issue is the lack of close faculty parking!

pros: Some flexibility in teaching approach/curriculum
cons: Department heads reluctant to back professors' decisions regarding students grades and cheating.

review_title: Adjunct professors are treated like tissues -- use 'em and toss 'em.
job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Austin, TX
pros: It can be fulfilling to work with the students who are working very hard towards achieving their dreams.
cons: Some adjuncts "pay their dues" as low-paid part-timers for years and years before being given a shot at a full-time position. It's demoralizing and dehumanizing in a way. Plus, it does a disservice to students, who are given a series of green instructors walking through the revolving door. Few can survive on an adjunct's income long enough to make it to the rare full-time position.

job_title: Floater/Employee Child Lab School in Austin, TX
pros: An excellent employer, staff and families are great.  Lots of opportunity to work hands on with children and families.  Opportunities offered to substitute for Lead or assistant teachers and to train Lab students as well.
cons: Were limited opportunities to come on full-time.  Very little if any turnover ratio in employees. This is actually not a con, but it was the only thing I could think of.

review_title: Its a good place to be
pros: On top of regular vacation, we also have paid leave for the spring break week and for about 7-8 during the Christmas holidays. If you enjoy helping students and making a difference this is a place to be. The atmosphere is friendly and most persons I work are very interested in helping students.
cons: The college needs to create better career ladder opportunities for its employees. They are working on it and its appreciated.

review_title: Review of NCC at Austin, TX, USA
pros: The people of this college are customer service oriented.  They are always willing to help and teach fellow co-workers. Always providing advise where needed.
cons: There are no cons to talk about

pros: Exactly what the title says. If you're hired full time, you're in like Flynn. Celebrate!
cons: This is not the place to go if you want to make a difference. The ACC bureaucracy is entrenched, and nothing happens fast or easy.

pros: Freedom to control what you teach.  Interesting because what I teach is always changing - makes you keep up with technology changes.
cons: A lot of red tape to get purchases or supplies.  Don't know whether class will happen until 2 days before start of semester because attendance may not be high enough or course may be reassigned to full time faculty.

review_title: Not a bad place but could be so much better.
pros: The benefits are great along with the time off. Working for students furthering  their education is rewarding.
cons: Poor salary structure with little to no way of being promoted. Raises are non-existent. Policies change frequently without warning. Policies change without consultation of those who perform the job duties.

job_title: Senior Computer Lab Support Technician in Austin, TX
pros: Great benefits! Three weeks vacation, plus spring break and winter holiday. Health, dental and vision. Relaxed pace.
cons:
The college is in a transition period from a la carte style courses to pathways. The future is uncertain.
Education sector pay scales.

pros: I was an adjunct there and everyone I encountered was easy to get along with and helpful! The mentoring system for adjuncts was great.
cons: No cons that I know of or directly experienced, except for the usual low adjunct salary, otherwise everything was great!

review_title: It's great job for full-time students
pros: People are really nice here. Work is chill. Just composes of doing laundry dishes and preparing snacks. Recommend for nutrition students who want some more experience. Pays well. Allowed to listen to music.
cons: Job is very repetitive - which is expected. You show at the same time and do the same thing. This can also be considered a pro for those who like this type of job.

pros: It is hard to hired on as a permanent employee
cons: High turn over rate because of the rate of pay!! People move on to brighter and better employment. Half of the staff is hourly employee with no benefits.

review_title: STAY AWAY FROM ACC IT DEPT!
job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst in Austin, TX
pros: Some individuals I worked with at ACC were very good natured people that had been there for a few years, but were thinking of leaving due to the new changes from hiring unqualified upper management who intentionally create a hazardous work environment.
cons:
Where to start ... as a Senior Business Systems Analyst within the IT department at ACC we had a team of 7 people, within 3 months, 6 of them are gone and the last person may be on her way out. The main problem is the IT upper management had started and stopped our project at least 3 times in three months and threatened to shut it down and get rid of everyone. The constant threat of loosing our jobs because senior management did not have an IT background and had very little experience managing teams (one was a former Secretary at a law firm) would create unecessary stress on our team, only for us to resolve and manage the project ourselves.

ACC cannot fire their employees and had even mentioned that previous employees who violated sexual abuse alegations, and discrimination charges were allowed to stay without any reprimand since they have to commit a crime to be fired. HR and management tolerance to employee bad behavior is very noticable in which I have seen senior management scream at employees in meetings and nothing would ever happen.

Because ACC does not fire their employees (even the bad ones and the ones that are uneducated and not a good fit for a new role they have been thrust into), ACC constantly hires consultants to perform the duties for their employees who are inept.

This creates a very negative environment to be in, especially within the IT department, since the skills are very technical. Other departments such as Payroll are pretty laid back, the environment is low-key, people do very little work and sit at their same desk for twenty years without doing much of anything different.

pros: Wonderful school, students and colleagues.  So many ways to get involved and grow programs and departments.
cons: Workload for faculty is heavy and for Department Chairs is heavier.  Very large school.

review_title: ACC is a great place to be!
job_title: Professor of English, Adj in Austin, TX
pros: Awesome English Department. The provide great support, training, guidance, and Judy Sanders (Department Chair) is excellent in every way.
cons: As an online professor, you still have to hold on-campus office hours. That precludes all mobility and travel. **Concerning wages, adjunct employment at any college is extortion, but ACC actually pays a little bit better than most.

pros:
I LOVE my job and the great group of people that I work with. I work at the Learning Lab located inside the Accelerator. 
-Great team
-If a student, they will work with your class schedule
cons: Cannot work 2 different part time positions to get more than 20 hours.

pros: Option to get tuition wavers on some courses.
cons: Each department operates on their own, so your experience might vary dramatically depending on which team/department you join. The department I was in was resistant to innovation, change, or doing quality work. It was an extremely negative work environment.

pros: Being an adjunct at ACC means flexible work hours which you can build around another part time job's schedule.
cons: They rarely offer full time work or opportunities to advance, very little stipend even with years of prior experience, and networking or supervision is non-existent

pros: The people who work at ACC seem to be dedicated to helping students.  It's nice to work with people who enjoy their jobs.   There are some innovative, far-sighted programs.
cons: ACC has the bureaucracy of any large organization. It can be complicated and time-consuming to get simple things done.  Wages are low compared to the private sector.

job_title: Continuing Education Instructor in Austin, TX
pros: Working with the students was very rewarding. Loved it when the students reached their highest potential and graduated with the regular classes.
cons: Head instructor didn't treat the program as important as she should have for the student's served. Or students were learning impaired in college.

review_title: I liken it to a high school, very clique-y.
pros: The benefit package is good and the work is easy.
cons: The work is too easy, not enough challenges, too much idle time allows for gossip.

review_title: Great Community College to Work For

cons: The campus I work on is dated and has issues with mold - it needs renovations.  Also, the hiring process is extremely slow.

pros: Remote working available to part-timers.
cons: They will not let you work more than one part-time job at a time.

pros: The people I worked with were incredible! I worked there during my last few years of college and they were always so understanding of my changing availability every semester.

pros: It's nice to work in an educational environment. Helping returning students learn how to learn is something I can feel good about.

pros: Growing institution--several campuses, good opportunities, nice people.
cons: Mostly adjuncts with no chance of advancement.

pros: They really seem to care about students. They give adjuncts plenty of support but do not micromanage.
cons: The online portals can be tricky to navigate for payroll, grades, etc. but they are currently working to streamline them.

review_title: Austin Community College Learning Lab Assistant Work-Study
